content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Locate a round-trip flight from Buenos Aires to Beijing, leaving on May 28, 2026, and returning on June 3, 2026, check out one of the options and tell me if the airline for my return flight is the same as my departure flight.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current page is the Google Flights search interface. To search for a round-trip flight from Buenos Aires to Beijing with the given dates, I need to update the origin, destination, and travel dates using the respective input fields.
Action: Type [13]; Buenos Aires
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure city is now set to Buenos Aires. The next step is to enter the destination city, which should be Beijing.
Action: Type [14]; Beijing
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Both the origin (Buenos Aires) and destination (Beijing) have been entered. Next, I need to select the travel dates: departure (May 28, 2026) and return (June 3, 2026).
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently showing dates in September and October, but the target departure date is May 28, 2026. I need to navigate forward several months to reach May 2026 using the "Next" button.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing October and November, but the target departure date is May 2026. I need to keep clicking the "Next" button to move forward several more months.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying November and December. I need to keep clicking the "Next" button to navigate to May 2026 for the required departure date.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying December 2025 and January 2026. I need to continue clicking the "Next" button to move forward to May 2026 for the correct departure date.
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing January and February 2026. I still need to keep clicking the "Next" button to reach May 2026 for the desired departure date.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently displaying February and March 2026. I need to continue clicking the "Next" button to reach May 2026 for the required departure date.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now displaying March and April 2026. I need to continue clicking the "Next" button to reach May 2026, as the departure date required is May 28, 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar on the right now displays May 2026, which includes the required departure date of May 28, 2026. I should select May 28 (element [70]) as the departure date.
Action: Click [70]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date (May 28, 2026) is selected. Now, I need to select the return date, which should be June 3, 2026. I should click the "Next" button to view the dates for June 2026.
Action: Click [78]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now showing June 2026, so I can select June 3, 2026, as the return date (element [49]). After selecting, I will need to confirm the dates.
Action: Click [49]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Both the departure (May 28, 2026) and return (June 3, 2026) dates have been selected. The next step is to confirm these selections and search for flights.
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: All the required information (origin, destination, and travel dates) has been entered. The next step is to perform the search for available flights by clicking the "Search" button.
Action: Click [22]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search results show several round-trip flight options from Buenos Aires to Beijing for the requested dates. To determine if the return airline matches the departure airline, I should click on one of the "Flight details" buttons (such as [50] for the first option) to view both the outbound and inbound flight details.
Action: Click [50]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The details shown currently focus on the departure (outbound) flight only, operated by Ethiopian Airlines from Buenos Aires (EZE) on May 28. To compare the airline for the return leg, I need to scroll down or look further in the flight details to check the return (inbound) flight's airline.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; down
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.9

content:
Thought: The current results show alternative flight options, but not the return leg for the previously selected Ethiopian Airlines round-trip. The previously shown flights under Ethiopian covered only the outbound journey. To answer if the return flight is with the same airline, I need to scroll up and double-check if a return segment for the Ethiopian ticket is on the same carrier.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.92
